 - 94 - Annex 4 Page 1 of 2 PHILIPPINES WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT PROJECT Criteria for Selection of Systems for Improvement Background 1. For systems improvement and repair, the project continues the program approach adopted under the IOSP II (Loan 3607-PH), which is under implementation. The strategy of the project as well as IOSP II is to improve systems in which: (a) water resources are adequate to justify improvements; (b) the need for improvements (or repairs) is technically and economically justified; (c) water users want these improvements and are willing to contribute; and (d) there is a reasonable chance that the improved, or repaired, system will be sustained because of the involvement of water users from the start, their commitment to maintain the system, and expressed readiness' to assume O&M responsibilities of "their" subsystem.2 2. Accordingly, all NIS were screened and ranked based on technical, institutional and economic criteria as follows: Technical Criteria: (a) Adequacy of water resources at 80% exceedance to irrigate a larger area than that presently irrigated. Clearly, if irrigated areas, particularly during dry seasons, already use all available water resources effectively,3 or if the entire service area was already irrigated, there would have been little justification for improving the system. (b) Completeness of hydrologic data: the analysis indicted above required continuous and reliable hydrologic data of at least 8 years. Consequently, systems with shorter hydrologic data were dropped during initial screening. Institutional Criteria: (c) Beneficiaries would have to be organized for the effective operation of the IAs. This criterion reflects the experience in NIS showing a close relationship between IA management, degree of cooperation amongst IA members, experience in O&M, financial status of an IA and the functioning of the irrigation system. 'In the form of a signed Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with NIA in which the Irrigators' Association formally agrees to assume full operational and maintenance responsibility. 2 The subsystem could be either a lateral or a sublateral canal, that conveys water to the area in which the IA is functioning. 3 That is, the overall water-use efficiency during critical periods was in the order of 45% or more, which is considered normal for open, unlined, irrigation systems.

Such a commitment is consistent with the strategy of the project to turn over the responsibility of operating and maintaining components of the systems to capable and willing IAs. Economic Criteria: (f) The economic selection criterion was that each system selected for improvement would have an economic rate of return of not less than 10%. The Selection Process 3. When preparation of IOSP II started, all 165 NIS existing at that time were initially screened based on supply and demand of water, considering available water resources (rainfall and river flow) and existing cropping patterns. Systems in which water resources were already completely utilized or those with unavailable or deficient records were dropped and 61 systems remained on the long list. This list was screened and ranked in accordance with the following point system: Adequacy of water supply .............................. 25% Effectiveness of IA .............................. 10% Commitment of IAs (and members) for O&M ......................... 40% Economic viability .............................. 25% 4. Of the 61 systems on the long list, NIA selected 35 systems and undertook their detailed preparation. At appraisal of IOSP II, 18 of these systems were taken up for improvement. For the rest, there were doubts about water availability, and, therefore, a hydrological re-assessment was considered necessary. This was undertaken by a team of consultants in 1994 as part of preparation of this project.  - 106 - ANNEX 6 Page 1 of 2 PHILIPPINES WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT PROJECT Detailed Activities Under Svstem Improvement 1. The system improvement will have the objective of generating additional irrigation within the service area of each NIS selected for improvement under the project, by increasing the efficiency of the use of available water and assuring its equitable distribution, as well as reducing the flooding of the low-lying lands by improvement of drainage. The higher efficiency of water use and its equitable distribution will be achieved by: (i) improving the irrigation network; and (ii) introduction of good water management. 2. Improvement of the Irrization Network. This will include the following activities: (a) rehabilitating the control gates of the undersluices and canal head regulators at the diversion structure on the river and carrying out other improvements to assure the diversion of the available river supplies to the canal as needed; (b) improving the existing and constructing new check structures on the drains in the service area to divert the flow in the drains, received from their own catchments or from the return flow from the upper irrigated areas, to irrigate the lower lands in the service area; (c) improving the irrigation network (resectioning for the discharge requirement based on the cropping calendar, desilting, strengthening banks, and repairing damaged structures) to assure the carrying capacity with minimum transmission losses (may require lining of canal reaches where seepage losses are established to be high) to deliver the full quantity of water to each section of the service area, and provide sufficient regulation and control structures to implement good water management (for this purpose, the gates on the heads of the laterals and at the tumouts will be made fully operational, and water level in the canals maintained by introducing new long-crested regulating structures to the extent possible and assuring the operation of the existing check structure gates); and (d) providing sediment exclusion/ejection structures, wherever sediment problem is acute, to assure the availability of the full canal capacity during an irrigation season. 3. Introduction of Good Water Manafement. This will involve improving the water distribution on the irrigation network and assuring the cooperation of the IAs in the distribution of water beyond the tumouts or on the laterals which may be taken over by them for O&M. The activities will include:
 - 107 - ANNEX 6 Page 2 of 2 (a) reviewing with the lAs the cropping calendar for possible changes (substitution of crops, specially during the dry season; delaying or bringing forward the land preparation or sowing period, etc.) to obtain a better match of the rainfall, river supplies available for irrigation, and the water demand of the irrigated crops; (b) arranging IA's cooperation so that the farmers rigidly follow the agreed revised cropping calendar to avoid the dislocation of the plan of operation of the network; (c) improving (instituting if it does not exist) a system of collecting information and its transmission (facilities for transmission to be provided if not available) to the operational control center from each section of the service area, relating to the status of cultivation and rainfall, at regular intervals to facilitate system operation; (d) introducing a system of operational controls and monitoring for assuring water distribution on the network according to demand; (e) organizing LAs to distribute water equitably to all the farmers on a tumout or a lateral (if IA controlled) either through rotational irrigation (if the farmers prefer a bigger stream to irrigate their farmns) or a continuous supply. The IA will ensure that no over irrigation is carried out and that: (i) the control gates are opened and closed at the specified time, and (ii) farmers maintain field channels to convey water from the tumout to the farms and do not resort to field-to-field irrigation; (f) agreeing with the IA, in situations of water shortage (this occurs in most NIS in the dry season), the pattern of irrigated cropping which would result in good water use and ensure equity; (g) establishing a system of recording the deliveries at the heads of the system network, lateral canals, tumouts, and the reuse check structure; monitoring that such record is maintained; and analyzing water use by sections, for each crop season, to identify where the water use was excessive or short of requirements, and to plan remedial measures in the next season; (h) improving service roads along the canals for effective O&M; and (i) assuring proper funding for the O&M by NIA or transferring the channels to IAs and insisting on agreed maintenance.

NIA follows the following accounting policies: (a) Fixed assets are recorded at cost and repairs that prolong the life of the assets are capitalized. (b) Depreciation is computed on a straight line basis, based on the book value of a group of assets rather than the value of the individual assets. (c) Allowance for bad debts is maintained at 2% of the receivables outstanding at the end of the year. (d) Trade income is recognized on a cash basis and receivables are recorded once the service is rendered, but the income is recognized only when the cash is collected. (e) Loan amortization and equity payments are recognized as income rather than reduction of an asset. Similarly, NIA recognizes the entire proceeds from the sale
 - 110 - ANNEX 7 Page 3 of 27 of an asset as income rather than the difference between the book value and the sale price. m. FINANCIAL CONDITION Present Situation 10. A number of recurring problems, arising both from operational and policy considerations, make it difficult to fully comprehend NIA's financial condition. Operationally, a clear picture regarding NIA's finances does not emerge, in part because of lack of uniformity in recording entries or failure to specify procedures in making them. For example, the lack of clearly stated procedures in transferring records from the work-in-process accounts to the appropriate accounts contributes to overstatement of the work-in-progress accounts with resultant understatement of the amount charged to depreciation. Thus, a significant proportion of the assets reported in the 1994 accounts (36%) remain classified as being "in-progress", whereas the actual picture may be different. This basic problem is further exacerbated by a number of other factors, which inter alia include the following. (a) Lack of supporting documents to reconcile accounts some of which were transferred from NIA's predecessor agencies. These accounts have been carried forward without appropriate adjustments. (b) Lack of reconciliation between physical and book inventory. (c) Unreconciled cash accounts, in part because of changes in accounting procedures when the accounts were decentralized to the field offices and the supporting documents were either not provided or were misplaced. 11. From a policy point of view a number of accounting practices followed by NIA are questionable. For example, the CIS amortization payments are recorded as income without corresponding adjustment to the loans outstanding accounts -- a practice which overstates both the assets recorded in the balance sheets and the income since the amortization payments are the repayment of a loan rather than income. Similarly, the entire proceeds from the sale of an asset sold are recognized as income instead of the difference between the sale price and the book value. Other important factors which raise doubts about the validity of the accounts in reflecting NIA's true financial condition and performance are: (a) the practice of calculating depreciation on gross book value of all items rather than on individual items; and (b) inadequate provision for bad debts. With respect to the latter, the cumulative provision made by December 31, 1993 stood at only P80 million; in contrast, as of the same date, NIA's accounts reflected total receivables on the Irrigation Service Fees (ISF) account alone at P2.8 billion (on an unadjusted basis), of which some P2.3 billion was more than one year past due.

Two aspects of the accounting practices followed illustrate this point: (a) as of December 31, 1993 the current assets reflect an accounts receivable of P4.0 billion, implying that NIA has considerable liquid resources. In reality, including overdues on the amortization accounts over P3.0 billion are more than one year past due (on an adjusted basis) and, therefore, not strictly current; (b) while it appears that NIA has significant reserves in cash (P2.2 billion, or 33% of current assets), the reality is otherwise as over 90% of these funds reflect budgetary allocations received for development and rehabilitation of irrigation schemes rather than resources available to NIA. Other aspects of the NIA's operation, that become evident from the analysis of NIA's income statement are as follows: (a) Salaries and wages and related expenses account for a significant proportion of NIA's expenses, accounting for over 80%/o of total revenues in 1993 and an even higher proportion (90%) in FY 1992. A number of reasons, some within NIA's
 - 117 - ANNEX 7 Page 10 of 27 direct control and others beyond it, have accounted for this. Firstly, following recent increases granted by the Civil Service Commission, salaries have risen at a rapid pace while NIA's collections have not kept pace. In fact, the amount of ISF collected has remained between P330 and P370 million annually, while amortization payments have remained equally stagnant, around P50 million. Secondly, the Government has transferred the responsibility for development and maintenance of the communal schemes to the financially strapped local governments, which cannot assume this responsibility. In the interim, although the development of CIS has been reduced, NIA is carrying these staff on its payroll, stretching its meager financial resources. Finally, NIA is over staffed. (b) Administrative expenses have varied between 18 and 21% in the last three years, but the amount allocated to meet these expenses is inadequate. In fact, NIA follows the procedure of assessing the viability of each office through a simple criteria: that the ISF and amortization collections should meet the operating expenses of each office. As is to be expected, each office gives priority to paying the staff before releasing funds for other activities and only the surplus funds are made available to meet operation and maintenance expenses. Following the recent increases in salaries, the number of viable offices has been decreasing. In 1989, 154 responsibility centers were viable. By 1993, the same figure had been reduced to 116 (Table 4). Offices that are not viable have to rely on financial assistance from the CO or other ROs and salary payments are at times delayed in some offices. (c) While collection expenses, as reported (only covering staff incentives, losses on palay, and incentives paid to Irrigators' Associations), amount to some 5.5% to 8.0% of total revenues and over 10% of the ISF and amortization collected, the actual staff time and effort spent in collection is much higher. Preliminary analysis in one NIS in Region IV indicated that almost all the staff including the Irrigation Superintendent, his assistant, the Water Master, the Ditchtenders, the Clerks, the Security Guards, the Drivers and the daily paid staff spent between 10 and 40% of their time collecting funds from the farmers. If the collection expenses are adjusted by the salaries of the staff in proportion to the time spent on collection, the ratio of staff salaries to the total amount coliected by this particular office in enforcing collection is almost 100% (see Table 5). While the particular NMS may well be an exception, and while it would be unfair to reach a general conclusion based on the experience of one office alone, it is evident that NIA's collection expenses, in relation to the amount collected, are high. Because of the viability criteria applied by NIA in assessing the performance of each office, ISF collections are of paramount importance to the staff, whose salaries may well be delayed if they have to rely on the CO or another region to transfer their surplus funds. ISSUES 19. The following issues arise with respect to NIA's accounting and financial operations. (a) Improper Record Keeping. The subsidiary ledgers are either not reconciled or do not have adequate information. In a few offices, it was observed that some offices do not maintain the subsidiary ledgers for accounts receivable at all, making it difficult to reconcile the accounts. The same observation applies with respect to: (i) the fixed assets, the register for which is not maintained by all offices, rendering the job of accounts reconciliation difficult; and (ii) cash reconciliations -- the latter problem arose when the accounts were decentralized and the accounts were transferred either without supporting documents or these have since been lost or misplaced. (b) Lack of Supporting Documentation. NIA inherited a number of accounts from its predecessor agencies without supporting documentation and these accounts can no longer be reconciled. (c) Oualified Opinion from Auditors. Needless to say, the failure to provide supporting documentation or reconcile the accounts has drawn comments from the external auditors, the Commission of Audit (COA), which has repeatedly given a qualified opinion on the accounts between 1985 and 1992. The common theme in the comments given by the auditors covers: delayed inventory count, lack of updated reconciliation, unreconciled accounts and incomplete information on cash, fixed assets or accounts receivable. (d) Frequent Breakdown in the Computer System. The DEC-VAX machine used by NIA is old and the maintenance contract with the supplier has not been renewed due to cost constraints. Breakdowns are common. Moreover, access to the computer is limited because, of the twelve terminals and five printers connected, only four terminals and two printers are working. Further, no back up power system has been installed for the computer system in case of power failures and the accounts are generally in arrears, at present six months. These basic problems are
 - 121 - ANNEX 7 Page 14 of 27 further exacerbated by the non-availability of a systems manual, which poses problems for new users. With respect to the accounting, only the CO General Ledger and payroll systems were computerized in the early 1980s and the systems do not maintain the subsidiary ledgers which are recorded manually. The limited use linked to frequent breakdowns of the system results in a substantial amount of staff time being allocated to posting the ledgers manually. (e) Inadequate Controls. Frequent breakdowns in the computer systems result in delayed reporting and little or no timely action can be taken to control the operations. While the viability criteria applied (see para. 18(b)) and the general lack of cash in the offices serve to limit the amount of expenditures incurred by any office, such controls can lead to distortions in operations as the funds are being diverted to pay salaries rather than operation and maintenance of NIA's facilities and schemes. The budgetary mechanism, as currently practiced, is ineffective in controlling costs. The Corporate Operating Budget (COB) is prepared to reflect annual expenditures, without any monthly or quarterly breakdowns. It is not, therefore, possible to conduct a variance analysis or demand explanations in the event of cost overruns. In any case, such detail at this point would be superfluous as the accounts are not available on time to take advantage of the analysis that the detailed budget might permit. (f) Lack of Internal Audit. NIA's operations are decentralized with over 195 responsibility centers. ROs have considerable autonomy in managing their budgets, revenues and even temporary staff recruitment. Under these circumstances, an effective Intemal Audit Division (IAD) would have been essential to ensure compliance with established procedures. At present intemal audit is carried by the Management Audit Division in MSD, with a total of eight staff assigned to auditing and can cover no more than 30 responsibility centers in any one year. The emphasis is more on Management rather than internal audit. (g) Accounting Policies. The present polices followed overstate the assets and the income and a somewhat confused picture emerges with respect to NIA's financial condition and performance. Specifically, the following aspects are of concem: (i) The entire loan amortization repayment is treated as income rather than just the interest. NIA thus overstates its income and the balance sheet. This practice should be discouraged, because NIA could, one day, be in a
 - 122 - ANNEX 7 Page 15 of 27 difficult position of showing assets on its books that no longer exist as they have been repaid. (ii) NIA also follows the practice of including the entire proceeds from sales of an asset rather than the difference between the sale and the book value, which overstates the income on the one hand and the value of the assets on the balance sheet on the other, as the book value of the sold assets is not written down. (iii) The provision for bad debts remains grossly inadequate. As can be seen from the income statement, no provision for bad debts was made between 1990 and 1992. The cumulative amount provided by December 1993 stood at a meager P 80 million. In contrast, the ISF receivable more than one year past due stood at P2.3 billion. The corresponding figure for the amortization stood at P 206 million. (iv) The depreciation is calculated on the gross book value of a group of assets rather than the book value of the individual items purchased -- a practice which does not reflect the true book value of NIA's assets. (v) The practice of reflecting all ISF and amortization due regardless of their age (the years for which the account is past due) overstates NIA's liquidity. At the same time, NIA treats the Trust account payable as a current account, which incorrectly overstates its current liabilities (those that are due for repayment in less than one year). Similarly, all receivables are reflected in the current account, regardless of their age. 20. With respect to the financial performance, the following issues arise and need to be addressed to improve NIAs profitability: (a) Improving Income. NIA has four important sources of revenues: ISF collections, loan repayment on CIS schemes, equipment rental and management fees on schemes developed. Revenues from management fees are dependent on funds availability for development of schemes and revenues from these sources are not, strictly speaking, directly under NIA's control. NIA's major focus seems to be in improving ISF collections and loan repayments as ISF payments are the single greatest source of funds. It has over P 3.0 billion in past due accounts and the collections on current account were only 44% (59% if collection on overdues is included) in 1994. NIA's management is aware of the need to improve them and has now begun to take action against serious defaulters, reportedly with good results. These efforts need to be pursued more vigorously.
 - 123 - ANNEX 7 Page 16 of 27 However, NIA has made little attempt to improve its revenues from equipment rental. This should be explored. NIA also has a considerable amount of real estate and it should capitalize on its properties to increase its income from these assets as well. (b) High Personnel Costs. The management is aware that NIA is over staffed and has drawn up a streamlining plan, that will reduce the number of sectors from four to three and the number of staff on its monthly and daily payroll by from the present level of 6,942 to 5,514 by 1998. However, NIA does not have the funds required (some P356 million) to facilitate the reduction of the 1,428 staff through voluntary retirement. NIA has sought the Government's assistance on this issue, and only P51 million of the P 100 million requested in 1994 was granted. As of November 1995, NIA had utilized P43 million of this amount, reducing the number of staff by 203. So far another 500 staff have expressed an interest in seeking early retirement voluntarily and it is expected that more would follow if the funding was available. (c) High collection expenses. As noted in para. 18(c), NIA's collection expenses are high. The practice of individually billing the land owning farmers -- the billing for water charges is sent to the owner and not the tenant -- is perhaps adding to the costs of collection. As of September 1994, NIA had a total of 551,631 billing clients of which 548,901 are on NIS schemes and 2,730 on the CIS. The latter amortize their loan payments jointly, while NIS farmers are billed individually. The logistics of retailing water (billing and collecting small amounts from over 551,000 farmers individually) for cash and in kind payments (in palay) undoubtedly increase the collection expenses enormously. NIA should move towards wholesaling water to lAs -- a policy that has often been considered, but not introduced -- to reduce its collection expenses. This may be an effective long-term measure to reduce the collection expenses. (d) Failure of IAs to adhere to terms of their contracts, which has added to NIA's expenses. Since 1980 NIA has encouraged the development IAs with a view to improving water distribution and soliciting the participation of the farmers in maintaining the schemes and enforcing ISF collections. To this end, NIA has contracted lAs to either maintain the canals and/or collect ISF payments. A number of IAs are not complying with the terms of the contracts and NIA is in the unenviable position of having to pay farmers, on the one hand and wind up doing the work itself, on the other.
 - 124 - ANNEX 7 Page 17 of 27 V. THE PROPOSED SUB-COMPONENT 21. The above mentioned issues have been raised both by earlier studies as well as the external auditors, unfortunately with limited results. In consequence, the backlog of the work to be done in rectifying the present situation only continues to build-up. NIA's management needs to urgently address the problems encountered in recording and maintaining its accounts to truly reflect its financial condition, and, even more importantly, subsequently manage the accounting and financial system to improve its financial and operational performance. 22. The objective of the proposed sub-component would be to streamline the accounting system and provide the requisite training to the staff to operate the revised system. 23. The project sub-component (cost details are at Annex 10) would provide funds for consultants to prepare a revised accounting manual and train NIA staff in correctly recording the accounting entries in accordance with a revised procedures. As the consultants would only train the Regional staff in the use of the manual, project funds would be used to finance the training of the other staff to ensure that in future the accounts are coded uniformly and in accordance with the revised procedures. 24. Consultants would also be recruited by NIA to reconcile all the previous accounts (both at the head office and in the field) and recommend follow-up action on those accounts that can either be no longer reconciled or for which supporting documents have been either lost or replaced. A time period of two years has been allowed to complete the job. 25. As already noted, it is essential that NIA now develop an Intemal Audit Division to reinforce its internal control procedures. It has been agreed that Personnel will identify some 27 additional staff that will be aligned to this Division to bring its staff strength to 35. The focus of the proposed Division, which should report directly to the Administer, should shift from management audit to internal audit. 26. As most of these staff have not been involved in auditing before, they will require some intensive training. Project costs include funds for the staff to be initially trained at an Audit Institute in Philippines and subsequently for refresher courses annually as needed. VI. ACTIONS TO BE TAKEN BY NIA 27. The following actions would be necessary to improve NMA's accounts and finance: (a) Under Philippines law, the write-off procedures are complex. In cases of unreconciled balances above P100,000, the accounts have to be submitted to the
 - 125 - ANNEX 7 Page 18 of 27 Congress for approval -- a time consuming process. In the meantime, NIA proposes to post the unadjusted balances in suspense accounts, in effect reflecting its true financial condition in other asset and liability categories, even before the adjustments are formally approved. NIA should set up a suspense account as the write-off of the assets is identified. (b) The Internal Auditing Department (IAD) should report directly to the Administrator. NIA should identify the staff and place the staff, after suitable training, with the IAD. IAD would change its focus to function as internal auditors, monitoring and ensuring compliance with policies and procedures established by the management. (c) Once the balance sheets have been cleaned up, NIA should alter its accounting policies to align them with generally accepted accounting principles. VII. FINANCIAL PROJECTIONS 28.  - 135 - Annex 8 Page I of 16 PHILIPPINES WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT PROJECT THE IRRIGATORS' ASSOCIATION (IA) DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM I. BACKGROUND 1. The concept of organizing farmers in groups was initiated in 1969 in response to the need to secure better water management by introducing rotational irrigation by section of a farrn main ditch. It required that farmers in a rotation area (about 50 acres) served by a tumout be organized in farmers irrigators groups (FIGs). 2. In 1980 the subsidies available to NIA were reduced. In order to improve its operating efficiency and also to enhance the performance of the irrigation schemes, NIA undertook to organize farmers with a view to involving them in the operations of the irrigation systems to secure better water distribution, reduce operation and maintenance (O&M) costs and improve the Irrigation Service Fees (ISF) collections. To this end, NIA introduced the Participatory Approach Program (PAP). Under the program, the farmers serviced by one turnout were organized into Turnout Service Area Groups (TSA) -- former FIGs--which were affiliated with a secondary level organization called the Irrigators Association (lAs). Under the concept each TSA was expected to cover about 20 ha (about 15 farmers) and some 15 TSAs would be affiliated to one IA which would serve, on average, about 250 farmers working on about 300 ha. Organizational Set-up for Supporting lAs 3. The overall responsibility for organizing and training lAs in NIA rests with the Institutional Development Department (IDD), which is, at present, under the direct responsibility of the Assistant Administrator, Systems Operation and the Equipment Management Sector (SOEM). 4. At the Head Office, IDD is organized in two Divisions, The Irrigators Organization Division (IOD) and the Irrigators Assistance Division (IAD), the activities of which are supervised by the Departmental Manager. 5. The IOD, headed by a Division Manager, is responsible for Organization and Training. It is staffed by a Division Manager, who is supported by three Irrigators Development Chiefs (IDCs) who are respectively responsible for policy formulation and monitoring of NIS schemes, CIS schemes, and registration of lAs. The IDCs are in turn supported by five Senior Irrigation Development Officers (SIDOs). One SIDO is pursuing higher studies and the other four are assigned to respectively monitor IOSP-II, registration of lAs with SEC, and the other projects being implemented by NIA. In addition, there are two IDOs supporting the SIDOs in analyzing and compiling data provided by the Regional Offices.
 - 136 - Annex 8 Page 2 of 16 6. The IAD is staffed by a Division manager, two IDCs, six SIDOs and 1 Agriculturalist. Of the two IDCs, one is away on a consulting assignment, and the other handles coordination with other agencies for providing support services to the lAs. Of the six SIDOs, two are involved in IMIS/IAMS training and another three are handling project Benefit Monitoring and Evaluation. One SIDO has been seconded to the WRDP and the Agriculturalist has been seconded to the IOSP-II Project Management Office. 7. At the Regional Office, the overall responsibility for implementing the IDP rests with IDD Division Managers, who are supported by SIDOs and IDOs responsible for supervision, monitoring and training of staff and the lAs. In total, some 75 staff on the monthly payroll are located in the 12 Regional Offices and UPRIIS and MARIIS, giving an average of 5.3 supervisory staff per Region/Major Irrigation Scheme. 8. At the Field level NIA recruits IDOs to work with Water Masters (WRFTs) and Farmer Irrigators Organizers (FIOS) to organize the lAs. 9. The program was initiated by using degree holder Irrigation Community Organizers (ICO), now referred to Institutional Development Officers (IDOs), to assist in the institutional development of the lAs. As the program was conceptualized, the IDO was to be the principal field worker to organize the farmers with the field level staffing varying with the type of schemes being developed. In CIS, generally each IDO has one project, where he/she lives and another project that he or she supervises part-time. On NIS the organizational arrangements were conceptualized differently. The IDO was to be responsible for organizing, on average, 12.5 lAs on 3,750 ha. 10. At present, the practice varies with staff availability and local requirements. IDO involvement is considered more critical in new projects rather than rehabilitation where the farmers are considered to be familiar with irrigation and where, albeit inactive, an IA is perhaps already organized. Because of this consideration and also to reduce costs, NIA trained the Watermasters to organize the lAs with the support of FIOs identified by the WRFTs. The FIOs are paid a stipend of P500/month to assist the lAs during the training and the organization phase, after which the FIOs are expected to become ex-officio members, serving as Advisors (on organizational issues) on a gratuity basis. 11. The IDOs were employed as group organizers on a contractual basis with their contracts terminating once the IAs were organized. Unfortunately, a number of them retarded the IA development process to extend their tenure of employment, which led to some disillusionment with their performance. 12. Staffing. Besides the 250 IDOs working in the CIS schemes, there are a total of 885 staff involved in NIS, the latter with varying degrees of commitment or time availability (see para 13). Of these 17 are located at the Head office, 75 in the Regions including UPRIIS and MRIIS, and the remaining 793 at the Field Offices (see Table 1). The Head Office and the Regional staff are graduates with varying backgrounds (sociologists, agriculturalists, economists), while the WRFTs have attained varying levels of educational qualifications. The older WRFTs have
 - 137 - Annex 8 Page 3 of 16 generally acquired school leaving certificates, while the younger employees may be graduates or diploma holders. FIOs are farmers located at the schemes. 13. Most of the NIS staff (779 out of 885 or 88%) are on the monthly payroll and, as part of the regular civil service, are paid from the Corporate Operating Budget (COB). Of these, 687 or 88% are WRFTs who, in addition to being involved in IA development, also undertake to coordinate water distribution, preparation of cropping plans and ISF collection. Their involvement in IA development is only part-time, leaving only 92 regular staff participating in the IDP on a full-time basis. Of the remaining 106 staff 100 are IDOs, paid from the projects on a contractual basis and, as already noted, previous experience has indicated that IDOs without a secure term of employment seem to undertake a results-oriented program without full commitment. The FIOs are paid for only one year. In principle, it is expected that they will continue to operate in advisory capacity once the IA is organized but only few continue to operate in this role without compensation. Procedures Followed in IA development 14. The steps involved in the development of the lAs in NIS are as follows: Step 1 Organizing the TSA groups, which discuss the operational and physical problems, select the TSA leaders and discuss the draft of the constitution and by-laws that will govern their IA. On being assigned to a village the IDO's first task is to identify potential leaders through formal and informal discussions. Potential leaders are appointed as officers (chairman, secretary, treasurer, turnout leaders) and together comprise the IA committee. Step 2 Formation of the IA. All TSA leaders, serving as elected representatives, ratify theconstitution and by-laws of the IA and elect officers of the IAs as well as the other members to the various committees that oversee the many functions of the IA. These, inter alia, include: - By-laws: to review NIA standard by-laws and modify them as needed. - SEC Registration: to apply for secure legal status for the IA; - Water Permit: to apply for permission from the National Water Resources Council to enable the IA to secure water rights and distribute water to members - Rig1ht-of-y: to negotiate the right-of-way on behalf of the IA from the members or others involved as the case may be. - Membership: to recruit and screen farmers for membership of the IA. The membership fee is P5. In addition members pay an annual contribution of PlO. - Finance and Audit,
 - 138 - Annex 8 Page 4 of 16 Others include Training, Service, and Grievance and Manpower Inventory to establish manpower available to assist in construction. Step 3 Registration of the IA with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). Step 4 Granting of NIA contracts, which is done after a series of meetings that lead to the signing of a memorandum of understanding after which the IAs are eligible toreceive contracts under the Management Turnover Program (MTP). Policies and Procedures for the CIS 15. Policies. Prior to commencement of a CIS, the IA is expected to comply with some basic requirements. Membership of the IA is expected to be at least 80% of the total beneficiaries of the scheme. The beneficiaries are expected to contribute at least 10% of the total cost in equity through cash contributions, labor or right of way. Procedures followed in Developing the CIS 16. Detailed procedures have been developed, and documented, to guide the staff planning and implementing CIS schemes and assist in the development of the lAs. The procedures are formalized and provide the legal basis for transferring responsibility to the lAs. 17. Once some farmers have expressed an interest in developing an irrigation scheme, the IDO should be located in the village in about six to nine months in advance of scheme development to organize the IA. 18. Prior to designing the facility, a general layout is prepared the NIA and a walk-through is conducted with farmers in each sector. Farmers' views are thus solicited prior to the presentation of the layout design to the IA general assembly. 19. Once the designs are approved, detailed estimates and the Plan of Work (POW) is prepared as prerequisites for release of funds from NIA. This covers schedules for procurement and delivery of materials, equipment, manpower and finance. The POW is also presented to the IAs for suggestions prior to finalization. With the design and program of work finalized, some two to four preconstruction conferences are held to agree on, and finalize: (a) the implementation schedules; (b) IA's role and participation; and (c) the formation of construction committees. The procedures and systems for construction are established and agreed upon, after which a memorandum of understanding (MOU) is drawn up stipulating the rights and obligations of NIA and the IA during the construction and the O&M phases with a view to assuring that the IA will play a major role in providing needed manpower and help in executing the sub-project. 20. At this point NIA also undertakes an IA viability study to assess its capabilities. Assuming that the review is satisfactory, sub committees are mobilized to assist NIA in procurement (Canvass, Bidding and Procurement), manpower mobilization, quality control, cost control and mobilization of farmers' counterpart (equity).
 - 139 - Annex 8 Page 5 ofl6 21. Prior to project turnover, a test-run of completed facilities is held jointly by NIA and the IA. A further "walk through" and an inventory of facilities is prepared. Claims on technical deficiencies are jointly investigated and, if found justified, a report is prepared. Repairs and subsequent works arising from the joint investigation are not charged to the IA loan. 22. An O&M conference is held to review procedures, identify O&M needs and responsibilities and appoint personnel or reactivate O&M committees as the case may be. Turnover takes place within six months of sub-project completion. Financial turnover entails IA acceptance of the total chargeable costs incurred and the amortization schedule. Physical turnover entails the transfer and acceptance of facilities. 23. At the start of the O&M, membership is updated, the organization of personnel is reviewed (if necessary elections are held to replace the officer involved in the earlier stages) and the by-laws revised. A system management plan is prepared comprising the proposed cropping plan, a basic water distribution, a maintenance plan. At this point a second IA evaluation in also undertaken, and if the IA is found viable, the IDO may be withdrawn although he or she may continue contact with the IA on an intermittent basis. IA Training 24. The Training is geared to assisting the IA in managing the associations and the schemes. The training modules, which have been developed with the experience gathered to date, include: (a) The Basic Leadership Development Course (BLDC). This three to four day course is given immediately after the IA is established. It aims to strengthen the leadership capabilities of its officers and emphasizes the process of group dynamics, interaction and feedback, and skills needed in leadership. (b) Financial Management Training (FMT). The course, aimed at efficient management of lAs finances, is provided before the project is formally handed over. The three/four day course is given to the IA officers and the finance committees members. (c) System Management Training (SMT) to improve the capability of the service committee to operate and maintain the scheme. 25. The above training modules have already been developed by the Head Office Staff, who have, in turn trained selected Regional level staff to conduct the training programs. The IA training is conducted at NIA's Regional Training Centers or some other training venue on a batch basis. The emphasis is on formal training. Whenever considered necessary, some of the above training modules are combined and given with other relevant courses with bookkeeping, audit and other management aspects.
 - 140 - Annex 8 Page 6 of 16 The Management Turnover Contracts 26. In the early stages of the development of the PAP, lAs were offered three types of contracts that were meant to lead to progressively greater managerial responsibility in the operation and maintenance of the irrigation schemes, namely: Stage I Maintenance Contracts, under which the lAs are responsible for maintaining the canals at a contractual rate of P660/month/3.5 kms. Stage II The Joint System Management Contract, under which IAs take over the O&M responsibilities within the IA area. The compensation paid to the IA is based on the break-even point. ISF collections below the break-even point are shared between NIA and the IA in the ratio of 60:40. If the ISF collections exceed the break-even point, NIA receives 40% of the ISF and the IA, 60%. Stage III Full Turnover Contracts, under which the IA is given full responsibility for the O&M of the facility. Once the irrigation scheme is turned over, the IA amortizes the chargeable costs of the scheme, much like the Communal Irrigation Schemes. 27. Following a review of the experience of the "Stage Contracts" in 1988, a new set of management contracts were conceptualized to overcome some of the problems encountered as the lAs tended to focus on ISF collection rather than maintenance of the facilities. particularly in Stage II contracts. The new contracts are referred to as Types I, II and Type III. lAs can opt either for the Type I or Type II or Type I and II combined. Type I Maintenance Contract, which is similar to the Stage 1 contract although the lAs are given a higher compensation of P1,100/month/3.5kms to maintain the canals. The higher rate offered reflects the increased maintenance costs. Type II ISF contract under which the lAs assist (campaign for payment or collect) in the collection of payments from the farmers. The incentive structure is as follows: Collection Incentives below 50% 0% 50 - 60% 2% 60 - 70% 5% 70 - 90% 10% 90 -100% 15% back accounts 25%
 - 141 - Annex 8 Page 7 of 16 Type III Full Turnover Contract, which is essentially similar to the Stage III contract. Status of MTP Coverage 28. Since the inception of the program, the coverage in terms of numbers, has been impressive. As of December 1994, NIA had organized a total 4,474 IAs reaching a coverage of 89% of the targeted 4,978 IAs (see Table 2) that are to be formed under the MTP for both NIS and the CIS. Some 89% of the targets have been met in CIS schemes and the corresponding figure in case of NIS is 92%. Some 1,827 groups have been organized (94.4% coverage) in NIS on an area of over 552,000 ha with over 444,000 farmers. Of these, 1,778 lAs have been registered and 1,542 had been given contracts but some have not renewed them. As a result, as of May 1995, some 1,520 lAs had contracts. 29. The IAs seem to have received more of the Type I, Type II, Stage II and combined Type I and Type II contracts rather than either Stage I or Type III/Stage III contracts. Stage I is less popular as lAs receive lower payments than the Type I contracts. As of December 1993, of the 1,520 IAs that had received contracts, 478 (32%) had received for Type I contracts (Table 3). The corresponding figures for Stage I, Stage II, Type II and Types I and II combined), were 15 (1%), 100 (7%), 411 (27%) and 474 (31%) respectively. It is interesting to observe, however, that very few lAs --only 41 lAs (2.7%) -- were working with Type III and Stage III contracts, under which the lAs have full responsibility for ISF collections and for the O&M of their schemes. In this sense, the PAP as is it being implemented at present, has achieved only limited success. 30. There have been selected studies to evaluate either the performance of the PAP in general or selected modifications to the program. These include:
 - 142 - Annex 8 Page 8 of 16 1) The Management Turnover of a Pump Irrigation System in The Philippines: The Farmers Way l/. The study based on the experience of a single Pump Irrigation Scheme in the Angat Masim Rivers Irrigation System concluded that: (a) employing selected and well trained farmers in organizing co-farmers can lead to active lAs at the field and distributory levels at lower costs and with better collection efficiency. (b) Compared with the previous approach with IDOs, use of FIOs in organizing activities can be shortened, made less expensive and be effective. (c) rehabilitation and institutional development must go hand-in-hand. 2) Farmers participation in National Irrigation Systems in the Philippines: Lessons Learned /. The study concluded that: a) IA development requires change, which is at times resisted by those implementing the program. Firm policies and support are required at the highest level to promote participatory approaches. (b) In order to make farmers' participation effective, farmers have to be organized by methods that build capacity for decision making during the organizing process. From this point of view, the procedures followed in CIS are more effective than those followed in the NIS. 3) An Evaluation of the Impact of the Farmers's Participation in the NIS Performance 3/. This study attempted to assess of the impact of the PAP on 77 NIS schemes. The IAs selected had been organized between 1982 and 1991 and the objective was to compare the performance of the MTP and the non-MTP systems in terms of collection efficiency (CE), repair and maintenance costs (RM), personnel costs (PC), dry season benefitted area (DSBA) and dry season rice yields (DSRY). It appears that on all accounts, the MTP schemes fared better than non-MTP schemes. The CE was 60% in MTP areas and 43% in non-MTP areas. The RM costs were, on average, some 30% lower in the MTP areas than the non-MTP areas -- the figures for 1991 being P380/ha and P540/ha respectively. The PC costs in MTP areas were also lower (P340/ha vs. P450/ha) which, the study IIMI Country Paper - The Philippines - No. 2 2/NIACONSULT, INC. December 1993. 3/NIACONSULT, INC.- 1993.
 - 143 - Annex 8 Page 9 of 16 attributed to the displacement of the ditchtenders. The DSBA in MTP schemes increased by 40% as compared to 20% for non MTP areas. II. ISSUES 32. There is little doubt that the PAP program has been successful in achieving a number of the objectives established at the inception of the program (better water distribution, lower costs and better CE). However, a number of problems have arisen and need to be addressed to secure the accomplishments achieved so far and, where possible, improve on the base already developed. These are: (a) Voluntary Membership. Not all farmers served by the TSBA are members, making it difficult for the leaders to enforce discipline on all farmers in a TSBA. NIA has taken the position that in view of the past experience in Philippines with farmers groups, participation in a TSBA should be voluntary. Valid as this argument may be, the failure to enforce discipline among members is proving expensive for NIA and some other solution needs to be explored. (b) Weak IAs. Not all IAs that have received contracts are strong and coherent. Data on the number of lAs that are effective are not available, but it is becoming increasingly apparent that some 50% of the lAs developed so far are facing difficulties in fulfilling the terms of their contracts leaving NIA in a difficult position. On one hand, NIA must pay the lAs to fulfill its obligations under the contract and, on the other, it continues to incur additional expenditures to collect funds and maintain the facilities. (c) Failure to Enforce the Terms of the Contracts. In a joint management set-up such as the NIS it is important that both parties meet their contractual obligations, failing which either party should have some recourse to compensation. NIA has to explore ways to enforce the terms of the contract through sanctions/legal means or better training. (d) Frequent Changes in Institutional Arrangements in liaising with the lAs. When PAP was initiated, NIA employed degree holders -- (IDOs) -- to train the lAs. In an effort to reduce costs, NIA displaced the IDOs with Watermasters who were supported by FIOs in organizing the lAs. These changes had two negative aspects. Firstly, the lAs lost contact with the people they trusted which had a bearing on their attitude towards NIA. Secondly, although the FIOs were expected to continue in advisory capacity as ex-officio members even after their stipend was terminated, some have ceased to play this role. Farmers are generally suspicious by nature and continued contact through trusted officials is important to ensure both the formation of coherent lAs and to take timely action if the IA is being misled. (e) Inadequate Training. Leaders are trained once and the members receive limited training to monitor the leadership and take timely action if the leadership falters.
 - 144 - Annex 8 Page lO of 16 It is important to stress that the institutional development of IAs is a long-term process and continued support is necessary to secure their sound development. (f) Conflict of Interest in NIA with Staff implementing the Program. The long-term development of the IAs was jeopardized by NIA staff members, who feared that they might lose their jobs if the IAs successfully implemented their contractual obligations. The categories of staff directly effected were the IDOs and the Ditchtenders. The ICO/IDOs were employed on a contractual basis, with their employment terminating once the lAs were trained. Some of them, realizing that their jobs would be terminated, deliberately did not train the lAs to ensure their continued dependence. Further, the Ditchtenders had most to lose with the transfer of maintenance responsibilities to the lAs and they also attempted to delay the process. (g) Lack of Financial Resources has resulted in some disillusionment with the system. Some IAs have now begun to return their maintenance contracts as NIA is unable to pay either the IAs share of the ISF or the payments of the maintenance contracts on time. (h) Shortage of Staff in NIS. The total number of IDOs working full time on the NIS is limited. The WRFTs are supposed to facilitate the development of the lAs, but they seem to be pre-occupied with water distribution and ISF collections. The WRFTs perceive their role in IA development as being one aimed at legal compliance with SEC requirements and the by-laws rather than taking a comprehensive view of the strengths and weaknesses and addressing them either with the support of the IDOs or through discussions with the leaders and the members as the case may be. It was generally presumed that the FIOs once trained would continue to act in advisory capacity, even after their stipend was terminated. Experience has proved otherwise and some other form of compensation would need to be explored to ensure their continued participation in IA development. (i) Lack of Incentive for Leadership to be involved in ISF Collections. The IA by- laws specifically prohibit the leadership from receiving any incentives or compensation for spending their time on collection of ISF. It is difficult for any one to continue contributing their time day-after-day without some remuneration, which perhaps explains the reasons behind the IAs failure to effectively handle Type II or Stage II contracts without support from NIA. (j) Lack of Comprehensive Plan for Ensuring that lAs Progressively Handle Greater Responsibifliy. The PAP, as originally conceived had envisioned that the lAs would progressively move from Stage I to Stage III contracts. For some inexplicable reason, the program seems to have lost its momentum to progressively transfer greater responsibility to the IAs.
 - 145 - Annex 8 Page 11 of 16 (k) Inadequate Monitoring. The IDP monitoring is largely geared to reporting on events planned for any fiscal year, rather than on the progress in tackling specific problems faced by the IAs. This approach need to be reviewed, specifically with respect to reporting on the number of lAs that are weak and unable to fulfil the terms of their contracts. (1) Failure to Adhere to Established Polices and Procedures in Development of CIS. Data on all CIS financed by NIA are not available, but from the limited data available from projects financed under CIDP 2, it appears that the policies and procedures established under CIS are not begin adhered to. Of the 83 schemes initiated under CIDP II as of December 31, 1994, 22 had membership below the 80% required to develop a CIS. While the combined equity paid 8.34% of the total cost (in contrast to the 10% required) in all the 83 schemes, this figure is misleading as the amount paid in 14 schemes was below 5% and in one, as little as 1.7%. It seems that the IDOs are no longer working with the lAs in CIS about six to nine months in advance of initiating the construction as required by the established procedures because the funds are released late, and this perhaps accounts for the lower than required membership and equity contribution. The expediency of developing schemes should not over ride the need to adhere to established procedures as it could lead to lower arnortization payments. In developing CIS schemes, NIA is ultimately granting a loan to the IAs and it is important that the beneficiaries realize that NIA expects them to meet their obligations at all stages of the development of the schemes. To this end, the insistence on following established polices and procedures would demonstrate NIA's resolve to recover its costs. (m) Lack of Established Policy on Past Dues Prior to Rehabilitation of CIS. It appears that there is no established policy with respect to clearance of past dues when CIS are rehabilitated. Such a policy needs to be formulated. (n) Outlining of Collection Procedures. The training provided to lAs does not include training on procedures to be followed in collecting ISF overdues from its members. These need to introduced in the training given to the members prior to handing over the schemes. III. SUMMARY 33. There is little doubt that the basic framework to transfer responsibility to the IAs has already been initiated. In fact, when measured by volume, the number of IAs formed, registered and granted contracts is impressive. Although there is no clear picture regarding the number of lAs that are capable of fulfilling the terms of their contracts without close supervision from NIA, it seems increasingly apparent that a number of them are not performing up to expectations. Preliminary results of the functionality survey conducted by the IDD in late 1995, albeit only partial as some of the Regions had not submitted their reports, indicated that some 10% of the lAs were very functional, another 50% moderately functional and 40% were non functional.
 - 146 - Annex 8 Page 12 of 16 On the other hand, it appears that there are a number of good lAs that can easily handle greater responsibility, but are not doing so for some reason or another. 34. In brief, the IA development program has, in a sense, lost momentum. More of the same is being offered in terms of training, interaction with lAs and granting of contracts without a comprehensive action plan to progressively encourage the lAs to undertake greater responsibility. One example of this would be NIA billing the lAs as one entity, leaving it for them to bill and collect from their members. This approach is not being actively pursued even though it would be a logical step in preparation for NIA's long-term objective of wholesaling water at the head of the lateral. 35. As already recognized and accepted within NIA, the objective should be to ultimately wholesale water to the lAs as and when they become fully trained to accept the responsibility of managing the whole scheme. This important objective, which could result in savings for NIA and the IAs, would be met only if the lAs are well established coherent entities, capable of enforcing discipline on members and executing the terms of their contracts with NIA. 36. If the aforementioned objective is to be met, IDP would need to be reformulated. Considerable modifications in the incentive framework, training programs and, equally importantly, the present approach to interfacing with the lAs would have to be made to achieve this target. Specifically, the following aspects would need to be considered and introduced. (a) Incentives would need to be built-in to ensure that the IA leadership is suitably compensated for its efforts in collecting the ISF. (b) There is a need to encourage greater participation by the members in decision making while ensuring, at the same time, that the leaders have the capability to enforce discipline on the members. In order to achieve this form of interaction, the IDOs have to maintain close contact with the leaders and the members. (c) The IA instruction would need to focus on training the lAs for direct billing and eventually for delivery of water services by NIA at the lateral head, and, in selected NIS, for compete turnover. Moreover, the whole conceptual approach to training would need to shift to encourage, in addition to formal training, informal training through visits. Where possible, the leadership of the more successful lAs would need to be encouraged to interact with the leadership of the weaker lAs. (d) In some cases, the endorsement of the Barangay leadership may become necessary to prop up the leadership of the IA if it performs poorly in collecting ISF. (e) In extreme cases, it may even become necessary to merge some IAs. (f) Because the problems faced by the IAs may differ, the IDOs would have to be trained to recognize the problems and mobilize the leadership or the membership, as the case may be, to respond to a wide range of issues.
 - 147 - Annex 8 Page 13 of 16 (g) The reporting system would need to be revised to ensure that the data presented to the management reflects the reality on the ground. (h) The policies and procedures should be modified taking into account the points made in para. 31 (1),(m),and (n)). IV. THE PROPOSED IA DEVELOPMENT COMPONENT Approach 37. Clearly the resuscitation of the IA development program will have to be initiated at the grassroot level with the primary objective of ensuring group action and cohesion as the minimum requirements for ensuring discipline among members. The objective would be to secure support of the members in enforcing sanctions against recalcitrant members, while strengthening, at the same time, the understanding of the members to monitor and control the leaders. If this basic, but difficult, objective can be achieved at the TSA level, the foundation will have been laid to develop strong lAs and their subsequent federation into larger tertiary level organizations. 38. In order to secure this fundamental principle certain organizational changes will have to be introduced. The IDOs will have to interface with the IA leadership systematically and, in cases where the TSAs are weak, the TSA membership and leadership will have to retrained to establish the basic principles outlined in the above paragraph. ReQuirements 39. The strengthening of the TSAs/IAs would require that the IDOs will have to be regularly present at the meetings of the members, directing the affairs of the IAs in a way that all decisions have popular support and that decisions are seen to be made by the members. This crucial point, although basic to achieving group discipline, is not easily attained. The IDOs would need to have a personality profile that readily wins over the confidence of the members. Moreover, they would have to interface with the members in a way that he/she directs the group to a common cause and purpose without appearing to do so. 40. The approach would need time to develop. The IDOs have to be initially present at all the IA meetings and it can take at least 12 to 18 months before a cohesive IA can emerge. The initial IA training modules already developed by NIA would have to be supplemented by frequent visits by the IDOs: it is anticipated that an IDO working on a fortnightly visit schedule could handle 8 lAs at a time (on the assumption that they would visit the field Monday through Thursday, leaving Fridays for office work). It is also expected that when an IA is considered to be functional, the intensity of the visits can be reduced and the IDO can be redeployed to work with another IA. 41. The training of the staff to introduce this approach would have to be conducted by the proposed Group Organizer TA to be recruited under IOSP II. The TA would have to undertake an active training program to assist: (a) the Regional staff to supervise the IDOs and train them using the approach outlined above; (b) the IDOs on-the-job when they are attending IA meetings.
 - 148 - Annex 8 Page 14 of 16 42. Unlike the past when a number of temporary staff were assigned to undertake institutional development with poor results, the advancement of the IA development program will have to done by a core of well trained staff that have security of tenure and are exclusively assigned to undertake institutional development. Further, it is important that these staff be no longer involved in ISF collections. 43. It is, therefore, recommended that NIA develop a cadre of 174 well trained IDOs (based on a workload of 12.5 IAs/IDO) to support IA development in the NIS. As there are only 40 IDO positions approved, most of the staff assigned to undertake institutional work would have to be given related positions that have been approved but remain unfilled. The Senior WRFT positions (with assigned responsibility for undertaking, among other things, institutional development work) seems to be ideal from this point of view. At present some 1,063 positions are authorized for WRFTs, of which 591 are filled in. On average, therefore, NIA carries one WRFT for every 1,100 ha. Of the 472 positions vacant, some 88 positions are for Senior WRFTs, and the remainder for WRFTs. Clearly NIA has a sufficient number of WRFT positions authorized to select/recruit adequately qualified positions to undertake the institutional development work (see Tables 1 and 2, and also 6 of the Project File Working Paper No. 2). 44. Not all these positions would be required, however. At present, there are 17 staff undertaking Institutional Development work in the head office. They are supported by 75 staff (on COB) in the Regions and 42 IDOs recruited under IOSP II (see Table 1). Of the 75 staff undertaking institutional development work in the Regions, 18 senior staff would be required at the regional level to act as Senior IDOs to coordinate institutional development work and supervise other IDOs in their respective regions, while the other 57 can be redeployed to undertake institutional development work in the field. As there are already 57 staff available on the COB in the Regions, only 117 additional positions would be required. These are far below the number of WRFT positions available (472) and the proposed program can be implemented without increasing the number of positions. 45. The availability of these staff suggests that some 117 additional staff would need to be identified. These can be recruited form the 42 temporary IDOs (who can be brought on the plantillia in the Senior WRFT Positions) and the other 75 can be promoted from the WRFTs, some of whom are very good at institutional work and can be easily retrained to follow the approach outlined in paras 39 and 40. Where necessary, a salary supplement can be granted to these staff for undertaking duties beyond their immediate terms of employment -- the Government's procedures pernit payment of such supplements. 46. However, it is also important that the NIA's payroll not be increased. It is, therefore, recommended that the 117 WRFT positions that would be filled under the program be offset by corresponding reductions in the number of WRFTs on the plantillia from 591 to 434 (see Tables 5 and 6 of the Project File Working Paper No. 2). This would increase the workload on the remaining from the present 1,100 ha to 1,500 ha -- a workload that is considered manageable as the remaining WRFTs would not be undertaking institutional development work anymore. 47. If the proposed plan of work is accepted, the job descriptions of the Senior WRFTs assigned to undertake institutional development and those Senior WRFTs or other WRFTs

In case of really poorly functioning lAs, it may become necessary to deploy the FIOs -- unfortunately on a temporary basis -- to work with the IDOs and this would have to be built in the program. Some 2,608 FIOs may be required in the long term. 49. Moreover, the program would have to be target driven to ensure that lAs are given progressively greater responsibility. Each IDO would be responsible for progressively moving the lAs from Type I/Stage I to Type II/Stage II and Type III/Stage III contracts within a specified time period, failing which they would have to provide suitable explanations. The system would have adequate checks and balance to ensure that the IDOs do not play the "numbers game" and that the lAs are given greater responsibility only when they are ready for it. In order to achieve this objective, the Regional level Senior IDOs would closely supervise all the IDOs in the field visiting them while they are attending IA meetings and independently assessing the LAs when the IDOs recommend them for the next contract Type. 50. The development of this approach would require three essential conditions: namely: (a) the job descriptions of the Senior IDOs be revised; (b) an effective monitoring system be developed; and (c) the staff concerned be assured security of tenure, otherwise, as in the past, they would be reluctant to transfer responsibilities to the lAs. 51. The overall plans and targets for training the proposed 2,282 lAs to Type III/Stage III contracts in the NIS, including those already formed and those that have yet to be developed, are given in Tables 8 through 12 in the Project File Working Paper No. 2. The Systems Management Committees and Farmers' Participation 52. The development of an active participatory program, involving the beneficiaries from planning through implementation is also essential. Although the approach would be somewhat slower in the decision making, the longer-term benefits of improved prospects for sustaining the development are expected to offset the costs in delayed implementation. 53. To encourage participation, NIA proposes to formalize the existing NIA- IA dialogue through the formation of the Systems Management Committees (SMCs), which would be formed to: (a) reflect the farmers' views and experiences in the management of the schemes; (b) reach an agreement on the key aspects to improve the systems; and (c) to promote an active NIA - IA partnership. Specifically, the SMCs undertake to (a) plan the overall activities; (b) identify and implement proposed improvements along the same lines as the CIS; (c) inspect and approve, and (in the case of the IAs) accept completed improvement works; and (d) monitor and evaluate the individual IAs and the overall system performance. 54. Each SMC would comprise the Irrigation Superintendent or the District Chief (IS/DC), Presidents of the IAs and the Heads of the Finance, billing and Collection Sections in the IS. Outside agencies may be invites as and when necessary. The SMC would be chaired by the IS/DC and the Vice Chairman would be one of the presidents of the lAs.

 - 151 - ANNEX8 Attachment 1 The Proposed Responsibilities of the Water Resources Facilities Technicians (WRFT) In close coordination with the lAs, the WRFT would supervise and operate, the irrigation facilities under his area of control, productive and efficient. Specifically, the WRFT would assist the IS to: (a) orient the farmers, through the lAs, in NIA's policies and guidelines on irrigation operations; (b) assist the IS, with participation of the IAs in planning O&M activities; (c) implement the O&M plan in cooperation with the lAs and the members; (d) maintain operations records for his area, and submit consolidate reports, based on IA operations records, on irrigated and planted areas, water deliveries and distribution, crop failures, harvested/benefitted areas, payments of ISF fees and damages to irrigation facilities and structures; (e) In selected lAs with only maintenance contracts, supervise through the lAs, the distribution of ISF bills to the farmers; and (g) perform other related functions as may be required by the IS.
 - 152 - ANNEX8 Attachment 2 The Proposed Responsibilities of the Institutional Development Officers (IDOs) In close coordination with the Senior Institutional Development Officers develop the lAs to manage their own internal affairs and progressively handle greater responsibility, gradually moving form undertaking maintenance contracts to maintenance and ISF collection and finally, managing the entire area under their control. In the context the IDO would: (a) work with TSA members to identify the right leaders that would represent them in the lAs; (b) guide, without appearing to do so, to question the leadership about the affairs the lAs; (c) enhance group awareness in enforcing discipline among non-performing or non-paying members; (d) assist the leadership in maintaining records and present them regularly to the members; (e) ensure compliance with all SEC requirements; (f) assist the WRFTs to orient farmers in NIAs policies and guidelines and operations; (g) conduct IA functionality survey, evaluate the performance of the lAs and its leadership and recommend them for training programs, when necessary; and (h) undertake any other activity that the IS or the SDO may require.

Specifically, the SDO would: (a) supervise all IA development activity in the regions; (b) monitor the performance of all IA and provide periodic reports to the Institutional Development Department in the head office. (c) conduct/arrange for all training of the IA members and their officers as necessary; (d) conduct/arrange training for IDOs when necessary; (e) from time to time visit all IDOs in the field and supervise them when they are conducting meetings in the field; (f) develop a program to systematically give greater responsibility to the lAs and monitor its progress; (g) personally assess those lAs that are recommended for a progressively greater responsibility before such contracts are granted; and (h) undertake any other responsibility that the ROs or the IDD may, from time to time, require.

 - 163 - ANNEX 9 FPEPINS WATER RESOURCESR DEVEL,OPMENT PROJECT Draft TOR for NIA's Environment Unit 1. It is considered important for NIA to do something to better institutionalize environmental and watershed management within the organization, both to improve the effectiveness of existing watershed management activities and its ability to secure environmental approvals for new developments in the future. The potential scope of responsibilities of an environmental/watershed management Unit or Division is suggested in the table below. The most important means of implementing these suggestions is to institutionalize environmental and watershed management capacity within NIA by creating a permanent Unit or Division within either PDD or SMD for implementing such work and to increase the number of permanent positions assigned to such work. No technical assistance is required to take these actions, although there is little doubt that any decisions on strengthening environmental management capacity in NIA would be better informed if a suitable needs assessment was carried out. Provision has been made in the project for 3 months of consultancy support to: (a) carry out an in-depth analysis of NIA's environmental assessment and management (including watershed management) needs as a basis for preparing recommendations to NIA's senior management on the establishment and staffing of a permanent Unit or Division within NIA; and (b) provide some on-the-job training in environmental impact assessment to the staff of the Unit or Division. The consultancy could be combined with that proposed for the implementation of the sediment monitoring activities funded under the project. Area of Activity Particulars Environmental Managament * formulation, review, revision and update of NIA corporate environmental policies; * preparation of Initial Environmental Examinations, Project Descriptions, Environmental Characterization, and Environmental Impact Statements for new NIA developments; * managing all environmental approval procedures on behalf of NIA (liaison with DENR, public consultations, etc.); * in-house training and technical assistance on environmental design, management and approvals procedures; * technical assistance on design of environmental monitoring and management plans for new and existing developments in accordance with ECC conditionalities; * preparation of environmental management guidelines for use by field units; Environmental Monitoring * auditing/supervision of implementation of environmental management and monitoring plans; * reporting of ECC conditionality compliance to DENR/LGU/NGOs; * carrying out and/or supervising environmental monitoring of new and existing developments; * data collation and review; Watershed Management * characterization of watersheds of irrigation projects for input to project feasibility studies and design of watershed management plans; * erosion assessments in watersheds of existing irrigation schemes to provide a basis for ameliorative work; * sedimentation assessments (sources and quantities); * assessment of effectiveness of watershed management plans by field inspections and monitoring; * provision of technical assistance to NIA field and project staff to improve implementation effectiveness; * coordination with DENR and others regarding cooperative management programs; e provision of advice to relevant councils and agencies regarding watershed land uses and other activities which are incompatible with NIA objectives; and * training and technology transfer to NIA field staff on all matters relating to watershed management.
