 - 186 - ANNEX 13 Page 1 of 2 PHILIPPINES WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT PROJECT Project Monitoring and Evaluation 1. The project has multiple objectives and some of its development impacts will not be easily measurable. This applies in particular to improved water resources planning and management, improved watershed management, and institutional strengthening of NIA and the lAs. It is, therefore, necessary to have some proxy indicators, which would provide a reasonable basis to conclude that the project achieved its intended development impact. Appendix I provides a matrix of project objectives; key performance indicators; estimated values (where applicable) for baseline (1995), mid-term (end of 1999), implementation completion report (year 2002), and full impact (year 2004); and risks. The measurability of development impact of different components can be easily assessed from the matrix. Project inputs have not been shown in Appendix I since they are covered in the cost tables in Annex 10. The Progress Reports to be prepared by the implementing agencies will include information on project inputs and processes, as well as project outputs. Based on this information and the Bank review during supervision, assessment of the project development impact will be made by the Borrower and the Bank. 2. Given multiple components and the difficulties of impact measurement for some components, an overall assessment of the project development impact during implementation, at completion and after completion will necessarily be imprecise. It is proposed to facilitate the overall assessment by assigning weights to the different components as follows: Development Impact Component Weight Improved Water Resource Management 20 Improved Watershed Management 15 Irrigation Systems Improvement and Repair 35 Institutional Strengthening of NIA and the IAs 20 Environmental Improvement 10 Total lo0 3. The above weights, which are subjective, reflect the importance assigned at appraisal to the objective of the component within the overall project framework, and have no relationship to the project costs incurred for the component. A total score of 80 and above during project implementation and at completion should be regarded as a highly satisfactory project development impact, 51 to 79 as satisfactory, 35 to 50 as unsatisfactory, and less than 35 as highly unsatisfactory. 4. To further facilitate the overall assessment of project development impact, key performance indicators were chosen (Appendix 1) and assigned weights (within the overall weights shown in para. 2 above). The weights of key performance indicators (some of which are proxy indicators) are detailed below:
 - 187 - ANNEX 13 Page 2 of 2 (a) For the improved water resources management component, the development impact is extremely difficult to assess. One of the project outputs, formulation of a Nat:onal Water Resources Plan, would be the main (proxy) indicator, since this project output has the best potential at this stage to improve water resources management in the country. The indicator would have a score of 10. Other indicators would be: (i) the strengthening of NWRB (score of 5); (ii) improvement of national water data collection (score of 3); and (iii) establishment of a water information network (score of 2). Any shortfalls in the above indicators would result in a component score lower than 20. (b) For the improved watershed management component, the same problem of assessment arises and, again, one of the project outputs, formulation of a national strategy and long-term investment and institutional strengthening program for watershed management, was chosen as the key (proxy) indicator, with a score of 10. Since the impact of investments in improving the management of selected high priority watersheds, to be undertaken after the completion of the study above, is difficult to envisage at this stage, a score of 5 is assigned to this sub-component. (c) For the irrigation systems improvement sub-component, a score of 30 would be assigned if the increase in irrigated area in the improved systems equals or exceeds appraisal expectations, or there is sufficient evidence to believe that the irrigated area will equal or exceed appraisal expectations within a year or two after project completion. The increase in irrigated area is a proxy indicator for increased production, income and employment of small farmers and landless agricultural workers, which would have a significant impact on rural poverty alleviation. The repair of major structures and construction of silt excluders (also proxy indicators) would have a score of 5. Any shortfalls in the above indicators would result in a component score of less than 35. (d) For the institutional development component, the full score of 20 would be assigned if, by the end of the project: (i) 19 small NIS (improved under the project ancd the ongoing IOSP II) are completely turned over to the lAs and the responsibility for O&M of laterals and sub-laterals of other systems improved under the proje-t is turned over to the lAs; and (ii) NIA's total income from ISF and equipment rental from the 14 selected systems is sufficient to cover O&M expenses of these NIS. The above two key indicators will have equal weight. Any shortfalls in achievement would lower the component score from 20. (e) For the environmental improvement component, a score of 5 would be assigned if the reduction in the schistosomiasis prevalence rate envisaged at appraisal for two NIS is achieved and the prevalence rate for one NIS is maintained. This would be the key indicator. Other relatively minor indicators (satisfactory erosion control works in 31 NIS and sediment monitoring in 3 NIS, and establishment of an Environment Unit in NIA), which are not shown in Appendix 1, would have a score of 5. 5. Appendix I also shows the risks of non-achievement of project outputs and impact. These risks are discussed in greater detail in para. 6.14 of the SAR and have been taken into account in the economic and sensitivity analysis (para. 6.11 of the SAR).

 - 190 - ANNEX 15 Page 1 of 4 PHILIPPINES Water Resources DeveloDment Proiect Water Availability for NIS and Possible Increase in Irrieation 1. The water availability at each of the 14 NIS selected for improvement has been examined for its sufficiency for the target crop areas in the service area under the anticipated cropping pattern. In general, the NIS can be divided into two categories: 12 NIS depending on the natural flow in the rivers from which they draw water, and the other 2 for which water is allocated from the storages (Magat and Angat) constructed on the source streams. Besides the main source of water, most of the NIS also divert water from smaller streams traversing the service area or located in the vicinity. The releases from Magat are primarily for irrigation, power generation being dependent on the pattern of irrigation requirements. However, the available water at Angat has to be shared between irrigation and Manila water supply, power generation depending on the pattern of the two requirements. Though allocations are clearly defined at the storages, problems arise due to the priority for Manila water supply demands, and occasional energy crisis. 2. An assessment of the supplies available from the main source of each NIS was carried out earlier as one of the nine tasks identified for project preparation. Under Task 1, the 10 day stream flows at 80% availability were estimated. In a few cases, the data generated was based on very limited information and, therefore, had low reliability. The analysis carried out by the project preparation team is based on the Task 1 results. The flow available in most of the smaller streams traversing the service area, which is used for irrigation, is the best judgement of the NIS staff, except where data could be generated. 3. The cropping pattern at each NIS is invariably paddy in each season. The irrigation requirements for paddy have been estimated on the basis of pan evaporation and rainfall recorded at the nearest reliable meteorological station. For all NIS included in the project, the paddy evapotranspiration is taken as 110% of pan evaporation , deep percolation as 2 mm per day, the entire rainfall at 80% probability as effective rainfall, and water conveyance efficiency from the intake of the irrigation system to the delivery at the farm as 45% in the wet season and 50% in the dry season. A typical calculation of the paddy area, which can be irrigated in the wet and dry season at Tumauini NIS, is given in Appendix 1. 4. The results of the study (Appendix 2) are summarized below for each NIS. Magapit (service area 10.914 ha): Although the major improvement work pertains to excavation of drains to relieve the flooding during the wet season, low areas extending to around 3,600 ha will still be water logged where farmers are not likely to cultivate. Accordingly, wet season irrigation will be possible only in 7,314 ha. Dry season irrigation is anticipated in the entire 10,914 ha. The NIS pumps water from the Cagayan river which
 - 191 - ANNEX 15 Page 2 of 4 has sufficient flow year round. The intake is located sufficiently far from the river mouth at sea to avoid intrusion of salinity. Sufficient pumping capacity exists. San Pablo Cabagan (service area 1.273 ha): Besides the main source, there is one creek having sufficient flow. Water from this creek is diverted to the main canal. Areas estimated from creek flow (250 ha in wet and 200 ha in dry) are approximate. There seems to be a good probability of irrigating the full area in the wet season, but in the dry season about 100 ha would probably not get water. Tumauini (service area 3,650 ha): There are seven creeks in addition to Tuamauini river, which provide limnited water for irrigation. An approximation of the areas irrigated from the creeks during wet season is: Antagan about 300 ha, Malamag 100 ha, Parenza 70 ha, Totto 100 ha, Caronan upper 100 ha and lower 200 ha, Angeapar 50 ha, and Callagan 80 ha. Except for the last from which water is diverted to the main canal network, the others have check structures irrigating captive areas. The possible area from the creeks in the wet season is thus 1,000 ha, and only half of this area in the dry season. The available water remains short throughout the year and irrigation will be possible in only part of the service area in both the seasons. Magat District II (service area 23.187 ha): NIA examined in detail the water availability for irrigation of the entire Magat service area. Water is available for full service area irrigation in both the seasons. Moreover, the proposed additional area over the average actual irrigation (1,598 ha in wet and 1,972 ha in dry) includes about 900 ha which is proposed to be brought under irrigation from check structures on the drains. Angat-Maasim (service area 31.485 ha!: The main source of water is the regulated flow from the Angat dam, which is diverted into the canals on both banks at Bustos. The additional sources are the flow from the uncontrolled catchment of the Angat river between the Angat dam and the Bustos diversion structure, and the natural flows in the Maasim river. The water availability and possible irrigation areas have been worked out as follows: a) meeting the requirement of 2,110 ha (service area of two canals from the upper Maasim diversion structure) from the available Maasim flow, and making up shortages from the proposed link canal to Maasim river from Bustos system; b) meeting the requirement of 1,059 ha (service area of the canal from lower Maasim diversion structure) from the surplus from (a) above and diverted flow from Bustos system through the existing link canal; and c) meeting the requirement of (a) and (b) above (through the link canals) and the remaining proposed area (24,000 ha in the wet season and 25,800 ha in the dry season) from the flows arriving at Bustos dam.
 -. 192 - ANNEX 15 Page 3 of 4 Should the Angat dam releases for irrigation continue at the past levels, NIA's assessment shows that there would be enough water to irrigate most of the service area. However, the analysis does not allow for the obligatory releases downstream of Bustos for the river channel protection for environmental reasons, and the results are, therefore, tentative. During the wet season, a large area gets inundated due to higher water level of the Candappa swamp, which would need very heavy expenditure for protection (not included in the project). About 7,000 ha of the service area is, therefore, not likely to be under irrigated or any cultivation in the wet season. The proposed irrigation of 24,500 ha in the wet season and 28,900 ha in the dry season will be refined further during the detailed preparation of the improvement proposals. Camiling (service area 8.580 ha): The NIS gets additional supplies from two small streams, Bulsa and Cayaling. In the wet season, about 1,400 ha remains water-logged. In the dry season, water is not sufficient. In both the seasons, therefore, irrigated area is less than the service area. Balanac (service area 1,300 ha): The NIS utilises water from two creeks in addition to Balanac river. Water availability (approximate for creeks) shows that full area could be irrigated in the wet season. However, due to submergence from Laguna de Bay, about 100 ha may be too water-logged for crops. During the dry season, only 1,000 ha could probably be irrigated with the available water. Baco-Bucayao (service area 6.678 ha): There is sufficient water to irrigate the entire service area in both seasons. Pagbahan (service area 1.356 ha): There is sufficient water to irrigate the entire service area in both seasons. Jalaur (service area 8.862 ha): The main river has low flow in the dry season. It is reported that diversion of water upstream of the NIS intake is increasing. Water is short in the dry season. It is likely that water is being distributed thinly. No increase in dry season irrigation is, therefore, possible. In the wet season, water is sufficient but about 862 ha remains water-logged. The proposed dry season irrigated area would be refined by NIA further during the preparation of detailed improvement proposals. Sibalom-Tigbauan (service area 2,100 ha): The available water is insufficient during both seasons to irrigate the full service area. Dipolo (service area 1.465 ha): The NIS utilises the flow in three creeks in addition to the main river. The NIS actually comprises four independent systems with diversion structures at each source. The availability of water in the dry season is insufficient to meet the requirements of the entire service area. Andanan (service area 5.500 ha): The NIS, with the Andanan river as the source, is short of water, and transfer of water from the adjacent Wawa river is proposed. The
 - 193 - ANNEX IS Page 4 of 4 trans-basin canal is also to irrigate 500 ha. Even with transfer of water from Wawa river, water will be short for the dry season irrigation. The entire 5,500 ha could be irrigated in the wet season. M'Lang (service area 3.120 ha): The NIS utilises the flow in the Bulong and Lika creeks. The available water is short in the dry season, and only about 2,000 ha could be irrigated.

 - 207 - Annex 19 Page 1 of 15 PHILIPPINES WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT PROJECT ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 1. This Annex explains the underlying assumptions and the methodology used in the derivation of economic costs and benefits of the project, and the results of the economic analysis. The economic rate of return of the project is calculated for the system improvement and repair component only, since the benefits of other compnents cannot be quantified with any precision. An analysis of the technical assumptions (e.g., water use efficiency) used in computing project benefits with and without the project is also presented. General 2. The Philippines has become an increasingly open economy in recent years with trade, remittances, and private capital inflows each expanding rapidly, the last stimulated by the capital account liberalization of 1992. Financial prices are fairly close to economic prices. This is true for the exchange rate, interest rate and tradable commodities in general, reflecting minimal overall distortion in the economy. Based on the proportion of imports and exports in total trade and a weighted average of import taxes and export taxes, the Standard Conversion Factor (SCF) for the Philippines was estimated at 0.83. With the macroeconomic and structural reform agenda currently underway, the long-term average nominal protection is expected to decrease. It is assumed, however, that some degree of distortion vis-a-vis market prices in the economy is likely to continue, and hence a SCF of 0.83 has been used to value non-tradable inputs and outputs. Agrculture 3. Agriculture accounts for about one-fourth (22%) of the GDP and almost half (45%) of the labor force. The slowdown in the growth of the sector after the 1 970s has been attributed to: an overall downward trend in international commodity prices affecting the country's traditional export crops, continuous deterioration in the inter-sectoral terms of trade, macroeconomic constraints, and a series of natural calamities. The sector's problems have been exacerbated by the revised Local Government Code (1992) which devolved inter alia responsibility for communal irrigation, tertiary roads, extension, and natural resource management to the local governement units (LGUs). Due to the inadequate financing and implementation capacity of the LGUs, the delivery and quality of these services have been seriously affected. However, the planned level of public agricultural expenditures under the Medium Term Philippine Development Plan (1993-1998) represents a significant increase over previous years.' World Bank, Philippines: Public Expenditure Management for Sustained and Equitable Growth, September 1995.
 - 208 - Annex 19 Page 2 of 15 4. The recent liberalization of the trade regime in the context of the government's structural adjustment program has seen a modest fall in the effective rate of protection in the agriculture sector from 5% in 1991 to 3% in 1995. However, exportables continue to be taxed at 5% and the effective protection rates for importables declined from 48% to 38%2. As a result of the recent agreement to liberalize trade through the World Trade Organization (WTO), market access will be further expanded through the dismantling of non-trade barriers and reduction of existing tariffs. As requested by the government, rice has been exempted from the WTO regulations over the next ten years, although the minimum access requirement has been imposed. Project C 5. Investment costs. The project would provide for the improvement of 14 existing national irrigation systems (NIS) serving about 110,000 ha., and repairs to eight diversion structures (in NIS other than the 14 selected for improvement) and strengthening of Masiway dam. Investment costs would include construction of silt excluders, new regulating and control structures, resectioning of the canals, repairing damaged structures etc. 6. Operation and Maintenance Costs. These represent the average (1991-94) O&M costs for each system and are directly associated with the improvement of the NIS. The O&M activities include canal maintenance, maintenance of service roads, pumping costs (for Magapit PIS), and maintenance of control gates and structures. O&M costs are phased in, based on the percent of incremental area generated in each system after project implementation. 7. It has been agreed with NIA that the improved laterals of the NIS would be handed over to the IA for water distribution and maintenance of the lateral and sub-laterals, the responsibility of NIA being only to supply the required amount of water at the head of the lateral. As under the IOSP II, the lAs will share the cost of the improvement works. 8. Paddy is the main crop sown in the service area of all the NIS. Paddy production costs include cash costs, non-cash costs, and imputed costs. Cash costs include seeds/planting materials, fertilizer, agrochemicals, hired labor, land tax, interest on crop loans, and (payable in kind) include seeds/planting materials (non-cash portion), irrigation transportation costs incurred during the purchase of inputs for the farm. Non-cash costs service fee, lease rental,landlord share, harvester/thresher share, and hired labor (non-cash portion). Imputed costs include unpaid family labor and exchange labor (valued at prevailing market wage rates), depreciation, interest on capital investment, and owned land (rental value). A recent country-wide study3 indicates that non-cash costs account for 34% of total costs, of which shares of the harvester and thresher form the bulk (42%). Irrigation service fee (ISF) constitutes only 1 percent of the non-cash costs. Hired labor accounts for a significant portion of cash costs (32%) and unpaid family and operator 2 World Bank, Philippines: Recent Macroeconomic Developments and Reform Efforts, June 1994. 3 International Irrigation Management Institute,Performance and Financial Viability of Irrigated Agriculture in the Philippines, C.M Wijayaratna and Ma. Delia M. Valdez, September 1995.

These are expressed in cavans4 of paddy and farmers may pay either in kind or in the equivalent cash amount based on the official support price (P6.0/kg). ISF rates vary depending on season and type of scheme, ranging from 2 cavans/ha in the wet season for a diversion system (Balanac) to 7.5 cavans/ha in the wet and dry season for a pump system (Magapit). 10. Labo. Wages are largely determined by market forces with seasonal and regional variations. The slow pace of agricultural growth in the 1990s has seen the growth of rural labor supply exceeding demand, thereby increasing pressures for out-migration. Sustainable development is also threatened as population pressures on upland and coastal areas have increased, reflecting the lack of employment opportunities in traditional farm lands5. The economic cost of unskilled labor was estimated at 60 percent of the market wage which varies in each of the 14 NIS. This rate is assumed to reflect the marginal productivity of labor in its alternative use without the project. 11. The average wage rate for the 18 NIS is P70/day. The average number of man-days for paddy cultivation is 61, 77, and 77 for rainfed, irrigated (wet season), and irrigated (dry season), respectively. Since the project is not so large as to greatly alter the demand for unskilled labor relative to its supply, the wage rate for skilled and unskilled labor in rural areas is not expected to change as a result of the proposed project. 12. Crop yields were assumed to be similar with and without the project. All benefits and costs were adjusted to reflect prevailing relative economic scarcities of factors of production in the Philippines according to the following assumptions: (a) Project investment costs have been converted to economic costs by removing transfer payments (i.e. taxes and subsidies) and border priced using the SCF of 0.83. The O&M cost (financial) was converted to economic costs using a specific conversion factor of 0.78. (b) Prices (present and projected) for traded goods (rice and fertilizers) at im6port parity, are based on the most recent World Bank price projections of October/November 1995 with adjustments for quality, freight, insurance, handling, local transport and marketing margins, and processing costs. (d) Imported components were valued at the foreign exchange rate of P26 to US$1. (e) Prices of all non-traded goods and services were adjusted to border prices by using the SCF of 0.83. (f) The project evaluation period is 30 years. All costs and benefits are in constant 1995 prices. project Benefits 13. The proposed project would contribute to the government goals of poverty alleviation and improved food security. With a high rural poverty incidence (estimated at over 50% in 1995), the bulk of the beneficiaries under the project are expected to be poor farmers. The main benefit would be improved operation and maintenance of the country's irrigation infrastructure which would in turn increase paddy production, farm incomes, and employment. The annual incremental rice production due to the project of about 100,000 tons (65% recovery from paddy) will result in annual foreign exchange savings of about US$30 million in current prices by the year 2003. 14. The quantified economic benefits of the project are the value of the increased agricultural production net of the increased production costs and project development and O&M costs. The increased production will result from an increase in the presently irrigated area from 145,000 ha to 188,000 ha, and an increase in average cropping intensity from 133% to 171% for 12 of the 14 NIS.While yield increases are likely to be higher with improved irrigation under the project, no such increases have been assumed and the project incremental benefits have been estimated conservatively on the basis of increased cropping intensities and restoration of irrigated area only. 15. For the systems under the major repairs sub-component, the benefits were calculated as savings in future repairs or savings in O&M, or prevention of loss of irrigated areas and/or expansion in irrigated area, or a combination of these. The key assumption here is that without any intervention, repairs would be delayed by five years. A shorter delay would substantially increase the ERRs. 16. The non-quantified benefits of the project include: (i) additional income generation through on-farm and off-farm activities; (ii) better and timely farm operations due to improved drainage; (iii) improved public health because of control of schistosomiasis; and (iv) environmental benefits from reduction of siltation and promotion of sustainable farming practices.
 - 211 - Annex 19 Page 5 of 15 Technical Assumptions in Benefit Computation Water Availability 17. Of the 14 schemes ( service area 1 10,000 ha), two draw water from the reservoirs along with use of the adjacent smaller rivers, and 12 are of the run-of -the river type. Of the latter, two, Magapit and Baco-Bucayao (17,592 ha), have significantly higher supplies in the parent rivers than the irrigation requirements in both the wet and dry seasons; eight (35,206 ha) have ample supplies in the wet season, but are short in the dry; and only two, Andanan and Tumauini (9,150 ha) have shortage in both the seasons, but Andanan would receive additional water under the project from an adjacent stream. Cropping Intensity With and Without the Project 18. The area under irrigated crops is anticipated to increase in both the wet and dry seasons. The area figures are firm in some cases and tentative in others. Based on current figures, in the wet season, the increase would be 21,900 ha (52 % of the incremental area), from the following sources: (a) relief of flooding in the relatively lower areas where flooding currently inhibits cropping or damages occur if the farmers plant the crops; (b) repairs to the damages to the irrigation system and remodelling of the canals to deliver water to those areas whch are currently do not get water due to system deficiencies; and (c) diverting water from the drains within the service area or in close vicinity to feed those portions of the service area where the irrigation system can not deliver water at all or shortages occur. 19. In the wet season, the additional area generated would not be limited by the availability of water or the variation of water use efficiency, except in Tumauini (Andanan would cease to have a problem after the improvement under the project). The canals have enough capacity to deliver water during the wet season even at a lower water use efficiency. 20. In the dry season, the increase would be 20,600 ha (48 % of the incremental area), from the following sources: (a) availability of more area for the dry season crops in the schemes having ample supplies of water, due to better drainage; (b) improvement of system to deliver water to the areas which are currently not getting water; and (c) diversion of water from the drains.
 - 212 - Annex 19 Page 6 of 15 Only in the dry season does water use efficiency play the role of defining what areas can be irrigated and that also only for the systems which are short of water in the parent streams. Water Use Efficiency 21. Unfortunately sufficient data is not available for calculating the water use efficiency in different years (wet and dry). The irrigated area is recorded as any area which receives water (irrespective of the number of times received), and benefitted area is defined as that producing more than 2 tons/ha (less than the yield of rainfed paddy). Invariably, the volume of water supplied to the laterals or turnouts is not recorded or is not available to calculate the water use efficiency by sections. Even for the NIS as a whole, data for the supplies to the intake of the system is not forthcoming. In a few systems (notably Andanan), water is distributed thinly with the concurrence of the farmers. The water use efficiency for such a system, if calculated on the data, would be more than 100 %. The question during project preparation, therefore, arose as to what water use efficiency has a reasonable probability of achievment. The target of 45 % overall water use efficiency in the wet season and 50 % in the dry season was considered reasonable (the same targets were used for the reservoir systems, although the Irrigation System Improvement Plan to be prepared by NIA suggests examining the possibility of achieving 50% efficiency in the wet season and 55% in the dry season), due to the following reasons: (a) All the systems to be improved have existing arrangements for diverting water from the drains, which receive the surplus water from the irrigated areas, both from direct runoff as well as from seepage. The percentages vary. More such diversion would be provided under the project. Even if the area benefitting from return flow is of the order of 10 %, the water use efficiency would increase by 5%. (b) Evapotranspiration needs of the paddy have been conservatively taken as 1 10 % of pan evaporation although IRRI recommends 100 %. (c) Deep percolation losses are taken at a uniform rate of 2 mm/day for the entire area, although most of the soils are heavy and are under paddy cultivation for a long time. (d) Possible incremental irrigated areas in the dry season were determined from the water availability in each of the 10-day period. However, if a shortage of 20 % is allowed in the critical 1 0-day period, the same incremental area calculated at 50 % efficiency could be irrigated with a lower efficiency of water use. The project components dealing with the institutional strengthening of the National Water Resources Board, watershed management, and environmental improvement, have not been included in the computation of economic rates of return because their benefits are extremely difficult to quantify.

 - 217 - Annex 19 Page 11 of 15 Sensitivity and Risks 26. Sensitivity analysis was conducted to examine the viability of the project under adverse conditions. The analysis was carried out separately for the systems improvement sub-component also. The results of the sensitivity analyses are presented in Table 4. Table 5 present results for the sensitivity analysis carried out for the combined systems improvement and major repair components. The results indicate that the ERR is fairly robust for the adverse scenarios presented. In Table 4, the ERR drops to its lowest (16.5%) for the case of the project benefits being delayed by 3 years. For the case of a reduction in the incremental irrigated area in the dry season by 50%, the ERR is still high at 19.6%. 27. Switching values (SVs) were computed to determine the percentage changes in key variables required to reduce the project's NPV to zero or the ERR to the opportunity cost of capital. Two rates of opportunity cost of capital were used (15% and 10%) to calculate switching values. The results of the tests are summarized in Table 6. The SVs are high in general. Irrigated cropping intensity is the only variable that is relatively most sensitive. The importance of this variable is underscored by the fact that the main institutional risk is that of non-cooperation by the lAs resulting in a reduction in irrigated area in the dry season, which depends largely on improved water use efficiency unlike the wet seaason where the incremental irrigated area would increase largely due to drainage improvements.(paras. 18-21). 28. The switching values required to produce an ERR of 15% require future with-project yields of 2.54 t/ha and 2.3 t/ha in the wet and dry season, respectively. This would be below present average rainfed yields of 2.72 t/ha. Since no yield improvements were assumed in calculating the benefits with the project, this scenario is highly improbable. 29. The SVs for incremental benefits delay, a very real risk given the potential for delays in project implementation is 3 years at an ERR of 15% and 7 years at an ERR of 10%. The SV at 15% is relatively low, indicative of a fairly critical variable. 30. The lowest commodity price forecast within the probability distribution at 70% confidence interval for rice in the year 2000 (in constant 1995 prices) is US$181/ton. The SV at 10% ERR is $184 which implies a 34% fall in rice prices by the time the project attains full development - a scenario, while possible, is quite unlikely.

Based on the discussion of the technical assumptions in paras. 18-21. and the results of the sensitivity analyses, it is clear that in summary, the calculation of incremental irrigated areas, and, therefore, the economic rate of return, is not critically dependent on water use efficiency targets: water availability is not a significant issue in the wet season and for two systems (Magapit and Baco-Bucayao) in the dry season. Further, for the reservoir-based systems (Magat District II and Angat), the 50% water use efficiency target in the dry season should be considered quite reasonable. The reservoir-based systems. Magapit and Baco-Bucayao would account for about 72% of the incremental irrigated area in the dry season (14,880 ha out of a total incremental irrigated area of 20,600 ha in the dry season for the whole project). A reduction in the water use efficiency targets would, therefore, not have a large impact on the ERR. On the other hand, since the improved systems are to be handed over to the water users. and an essential objective of the project is to encourage the water users to improve the management of the systems, it was considered advisable to retain the targets of 45% in the wet season and 50% in the dry.

doc.abstracts: The Water Resources Development project will assist the Government of the Philippines in developing an appropriate policy and institutional framework to improve water resources planning, development and management; initiating an integrated and comprehensive approach to water shed management to sustain water sources; improving existing irrigation system efficiency, thereby increasing agricultural production, and alleviating rural poverty; improving irrigation services in the long term by accelerating management turnover of irrigation systems to water users and by increasing the National Irrigation Administration's (NIA's) institutional effectiveness; and improving the environment in irrigated areas. The five year project will include the following components: a) improved water resources planning and management - preparation of a national water resources plan, improvement of national data collection networks, establishment of a national water information network and strengthening of the National Water Resources Board (NWRB); b) improved watershed management - formulation of a national watershed management strategy and investment and institutional strengthening program, investments for improved management; and staff training/study watershed management tour; c) improvement and repair of National Irrigation System (NIS) - system improvement, repairs in major structures, strengthening of Masiway dam, and construction of sediment inclusion structures; d) institutional strengthening of NIA and Irrigators Associations (IAs) - staff training, consultancies, computers and incremental operating costs to facilitate progressive management; and e) environmental improvement - control of schistosomiasis, erosion control works; sediment monitoring, and establishment of an Environmental Unit within NIA and provision of training and consultancy to the unit.
